ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Baze Chemical safety is our top concern. In our manufacturing facilities we take special
measures to ensure the safety of all involved.

The policy on chemical safety at the Palestine Plant is to prevent the release of chemicals through
high standards of design and operation, and to provide measures to mitigate releases should they
occur.  Baze Chemical is committed to operating and maintaining the facility in a safe and
responsible manner and has the goal of no accidents or injuries.

FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Palestine Plant is an ethoxylation facility that produces a range of specialty surfactants for use
predominantly in the oil and gas industry. The process of ethoxylation involves reacting ethylene
oxide with various common chemicals, such as fatty alcohols and phenols, to produce a variety of
products.

The plant can also use propylene oxide instead of (or as well as) ethylene oxide in a similar process
known as "propoxylation". 

Regulated materials at the facility are ethylene oxide (up to 375,500 lb, or 49,000 gallons) and
propylene oxide (up to 45,650 lb, or 6,600 gallons). The other raw materials used in the process as
well as the products are not regulated. Both ethylene oxide (EO) and propylene oxide (PO) are
stored in pressurized horizontal storage vessels equipped with external cooling facilities.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The facility complies with the OSHA PSM rules as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119 and Program 3
requirements under EPA CAPP rules as defined in 40 CFR 68.

Specific design features and operating practices at the facility relevant to the control of ethylene
oxide and propylene oxide are:

- Purging with nitrogen after each transfer operation to prevent stagnant EO or PO liquid being
  present in piping.
- Facilities and procedure to regularly circulate the contents of the EO storage tanks, in accordance
  with r

ecognized and generally accepted good engineering practices for the storage of EO.
-  Circulation of tank contents controls the potential for polymerization of EO.
- Facilities and procedures to cool the contents of the EO and PO storage tanks, using chilled water.
- The design of the cooling system eliminates the potential for cross-contamination between either
   material and the chilled water.
- The provision of a scrubber system to remove trace vapors of EO or PO from vent discharges.
- Dual independent transmitters on each storage tank to warn of high or low level, high or low
   pressure, and high temperature.
- Padding of EO storage tanks with nitrogen to maintain the vapor space in the non-decomposable
   range.
- Automatic shutdown of EO and PO tanks on low motor power and on high pump casing
   temperature, so that pumps cannot be run "dead headed".
- Automatic shutdown of EO or PO injection to the reactors based on any one of the following reactor
  conditions: high temperature; high pressure; high level; lower stirrer power (which may indicate loss
  of stirring/agitation).
- Remote shutdown of EO rail car unloading liquid line.
- Remote shutdown of EO or PO tank liquid transfer.
- All penetration for liquid and vapor lines to the EO and PO tanks are via top entry, thereby
   eliminating nozzles below the liquid level.
- Secondary containment around the EO and PO storage tanks, sized for at least 110% of the
  largest inventory.
- Passive fire protection of the EO and PO storage tanks to minimize the heat input to the tanks
   during a fire and avoid conditions that could lead to a BLEVE (boiling liquid expanding vapor
   explosion).
- Water deluge system over the EO / PO storage tanks to suppress vapor dispersion of accidental
   spills.
- Operating philosophy that requires a minimum of two operators to be present during each activity
  involving transfer of EO or PO.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Palestine Plant operat

ion has had no accidents to report.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The emergency response program for the Palestine Plant is based on the premise of minimal active
intervention by plant personnel, other than shutdown of equipment, isolation of inventory,
and activation of fixed vapor mitigation water deluge system. The program addresses all the
requirement of OSHA regulations for emergency action plans (per 29 CFR 1910.38).

Coordination with local emergency responders is ongoing. Baze Chemical has met hosted meetings at the plant with Alan Fox, Fire Chief of the county Volunteer Fire Department on April 14, 2020.  He visited the facility with crewmembers and was given a copy of the facility PSM Program, Emergency Response Plan, and facility Safety Manual. On July 29, 2020 Baze Chemical also met with Shannon Davis, Fire Chief for the city of Palestine and Melinda Chambers, Emergency Coordinator for the City of Palestine.  They both received a copy of the Palestine facility PSM Plan, Emergency Response Plan and facility Safety Manual.  Information on RMP worst credible scenario and alternative scenarios has been provided.  The Palestine emergency services will act as "first responders" in the event of an emergency at the site. Discussions with response agencies and familiarization of first responders with the facility are ongoing.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

While there are no specific planned changes, any such opportunity will be properly evaluated and
managed through the site's management of change procedure (PAL-PSM-010) prior to implementation.

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

An offsite consequence analysis has been prepared in accordance with the rules specified in 40
CFR 68, which require that ethylene oxide be treated as a gas liquefied by pressure. As such, the
rules require that the worst-case release be the entire inventory of the largest container released
over a 10 minute period. As detailed elsewhere in this RMP submission, the

endpoint for this
scenario is 12 miles. This analysis is not credible, as it is thermodynamically impossible for the entire inventory of the largest tank of ethylene oxide to vaporize over 10 minutes. Features in place that would further limit this scenario include:
- ethylene oxide tanks are kept cool such that liquid temperature range is between 50 deg.F (the
   boiling point of EO at atmospheric pressure) and 70 deg.F
- the tanks are contained within a dike that is adequate to contain the entire inventory of the largest
  tank
- tanks do not have any nozzles or connections below the liquid level

A release into the diked area will result in a liquid pool at 50 deg.F, which would vaporize over time.
This release would be similar to the propylene oxide worst-case scenario, with a distance to the end
point significantly lower than the 12 miles determined in accordance with the RMP rules.

Additional offsite consequence analyses addressed in this RMP are:
- Alternative release of EO, based on a release during transfer of EO from rail tanker. Release was
   assumed to be stopped after 1 minute by activation of emergency shutdown devices. Distance to
   end point for this scenario was calculated at 1.1 miles.
- Worst case release of PO (treated as a toxic liquid per RMP rules). The entire contents of the PO
   storage tank is assumed to be released into the dike and vaporize over time. Distance to end point
   for this scenario was calculated at 1.8 miles.

- Alternative release of PO, based on a release during transfer of PO from tank truck. Release was
   assumed to be stopped after 1 minute by activation of emergency shutdown devices. Distance to
   end point for this scenario was calculated at 0.2 miles.
